title: Picacho State Recreation Area
text:
Picacho State Recreation Area is a camping, boating, and general recreation area located on a 9-mile stretch of the lower <a href="Colorado%20river">Colorado river</a> at the site of <a href="Picacho%2C%20California">Picacho</a>, a defunct gold mining town.
Picacho is a popular wintertime/springtime destination for boating, fishing, hiking and camping. This remote park is located in the far southeastern corner of <a href="California">California</a> and includes 54 campsites, 3 boat launches, and 5 river camps. Favorite activities at the park include stargazing, and bird and wildlife viewing (including the famous desert resident, the <a href="Bighorn%20sheep">Bighorn sheep</a>).
The mining town of Picacho sat on this spot in the early 1900s. The remains of a stamp mill that was used to crush the <a href="gold">gold</a> ore during mining operations is a popular hiking destination.
This section of the Colorado River is a popular stopover for migratory waterfowl - ducks, geese, <a href="ibis">ibis</a> and <a href="cormorants">cormorants</a> - usually seen by the thousands in spring and fall. Other waterfowl are found here year round.
Proposed for closure.
Picacho State Recreation Area is one of the 48 <a href="List%20of%20California%20state%20parks">California state parks</a> proposed for closure in January 2008 by California's Governor <a href="Arnold%20Schwarzenegger">Arnold Schwarzenegger</a> as part of a deficit reduction program.
Closure again seemed imminent in 2012 as a part of California's sweeping 70-park closure plan. However, Picacho SRA was never closed, and is fully operational as of 2013. A non-profit group <a href="http%3A//www.friends4picacho.org/">Friends4Picacho</a> was formed in 2012 to promote its continued operation.
